Mitt Romney did not inherit his money. I have no idea how rich George Romney, his father, was, but as a CEO of a middling car company he would have been well off in his day. Nonetheless, it was nothing compared to Mitt Romney's current wealth. Mitt made his money the old fashioned way -- he earned it by starting up a business (Bain Capital) and doing well with it. Yes, he used Other People's Money to leverage his activities, and the list of people who became very rich in the same way he did is rather lengthy. But inherit it he didn't. That's for the Kennedy clan and the Rockefeller cousins and the like.

I am sorry you lost money on the sale of your first home. However, everyone -- realtors, friends, families, magazine articles -- lied to you, when they implied that "housing only goes up up up!"

It does not, obviously. From the 70s through the early 00s, there was an unprecedented rise in housing prices, but it was a historical anomaly. Before that, people did NOT assume you could "always sell for more than you paid". Banks did not extend 30 year mortgages, or try to sell folks on "home equity loans" because they knew that homes could easily lose value or stay flat.

Hopefully you purchased your new home in Chicago more cautiously. It helps to be sure you do not overpay, or get sucked into the "always goes up up up!" idea -- and stay put. Five years is not very long to be in a house, and it is partly why you lost so much money on it.
Amen. The system did punish you for doing the right thing.

I can personally attest to this. We bought a house in 2003. It was reasonable and one we could afford. Even so, when I had to find a new job in 2008, the best price we could get was $70,000 less than what we bought it for. We easily found new jobs and had to move to a place with higher home values that was not hit as hard in the housing crash. In order to afford the down payment for the new house, we had to access retirement accounts and I had to come to the closing of our old house with a check for $9000. The worst part was that the $9000 just went to some rich banker somewhere. Again, we could afford everything we did, drove reasonable cars, and have no other debt than our home and one car payment. We have worked since high school and through college, never receiving a dime from our parents or a trust fund.

And yet, we feel like the system punished us for doing the right thing, while others who have trust funds don't have to worry, and unethical people got off with a slap on the wrist. The rich people in this country seem to think that people like me someone didn't work hard enough, but yet I feel like the only way to be wealthy in the U.S. today is to either 1) inherit it (like Romney or GW did) or 2) do unethical things that aren't illegal (not playing by the rules). The idea that anyone can get ahead on their own in the U.S. is a myth - the two best ways to be financially secure are to either inherit it (and become president) or steal it (and work on Wall St.)

Kudos to Jeb Bush for saying exactly what needs to be said. Today's Republican Party has abandoned the legacy of Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Eisenhower, Nixon (with the substantial exception of Watergate), Ford, Reagan and George H.W. Bush-- all men who respected pragmatism and compromise in governance, to embrace obstructionism, extremism and a rigid ideology that undermines the political process.

Thank you, Governor Bush, for speaking truth to power and taking this principled stand. If more centrist Republicans also speak out, perhaps there will be hope for the Grand Old Party yet.

I think vouchers, combined with competition and portability would be much better than what we have now; would not require a complicated set of laws nor a large bureaucracy to operate; and would put downward pressure on the overall cost. I do not believe a public option or a single-payer would have these benefits.

David Frum's suggestion to consolidate heathcare regulation at the federal level might work if the federal government could avoid micromanaging every single little detail of what is covered, especially in regard to discretionary treatments or treatments for common, non-chronic conditions. However, judging from the requirements that are currently being put on employers through the AHCAA, with their attendant controversy, I am not very hopeful in this regard.

I am not one to let the perfect stand in the way of the good, so I hope that some sort of compromise can be found that can fix the worst features of our current system without eliminating the best.

(I don't worry too much about a group's funding as long as its ideas are sound and can stand on their own. Here's another physicians' group to check out: www.aapsonline.org )

Why just Siachen, it would be great if there were no military personnel on any border, with hostile elements or not. But Pakistan cannot be trusted on any border. Pakistan would love to have India withdraw, so they can surreptitiously gain tactical advantage. You can count on them and their supporters in the media (such as Brian Cloughey) to put pressure on India to withdraw.
The world's energies would be better spent in asking Pakistan to accept the Line Of Control as the International Border. That would signal the end of Pakistan's intent to stop playing games on the Kashmir border (and the Afghan border at that point), and only then would Siachen's demilitarization become a plan worth considering.

The premise is deeply flawed by the fact that Pakistan is nowhere near the Siachen glacier. India both controls Siachen and the high ground surrounding it; and therefore the passes through which the Pakistanis would need to enter into Siachen. With the US increasingly losing its patience with Pakistan's duplicitous behavior, it is odd, to say the least, that the NYT would push for India to cede territory that it already holds in exchange for empty Pakistani promises. The sepoys at India Ink may have forgotten Kargil or the Mumbai terrorism or the 65 year old history of Pakistan's aggressive brinkmanship, but, fortunately, not all of their countrymen are quite as sanguine about attaining "peace in our time". Nobody is stopping Pakistan from withdrawing from its positions far outside of Siachen. Kayani is welcome to unilaterally disengage from here at anytime.

As for "no strategic importance" for Siachen, or the anything-but-neutral observations by the likes of Cloughley or Cohen, who have made their careers scratching the back of Pakistan's rogue military, they overlook how China has already seized parts of Kashmir that flank Siachen. Some of it was ceded away by Pakistan to its best-friend-forever, and there is nothing to stop Pakistan from generously gifting Siachen to China if India falls for this feint.

Wrong! You don't take into account the policies of the current government. Reforms have stalled completely for the last seven years whereas there has been a massive expansion of subsidies and entitlements - which led to a fiscal deficit and a current a/c deficit coupled with inflation. Investors have lost confidence because productivity enhancing reforms have stalled completely. So India did have a trend rate of growth around 8-9% - and that's what the growth rate was even after the 2008 crisis - the current slowdown is produced by incompetent economic management of the present government. (Lot more reforms were carried out in 1991-96 and then again in 1999-2004).

The period between 2004 and 2007 experienced
high growth because of low interest rates and
easy access to credit in India and globally. The
recession in 2008 and the financial crisis ended
easy credit availability. India got through this period
with less angst because the banks were govt owned
and didn't finance mortgages to create the bubble
a la USA and Europe. Indian govt loosened up the
monetary policy to spur growth which materialized
but also spawned high inflation. Subsequent
tightening up of money supply and the rise(13 times)
in interest rate crimped the purchasing power of
the consumers and dampened the investment.
Somehow Indian economists have taken the period
of 2004 -2007 as a norm and made forecasts of 9% to 10% growth.Some even straight lined this rate
to predict Indian GDP surpassing USA's in 2050.
Reality has hit India. Reforms may be an issue,
but no one has figured out the policies to grow
at 9% with moderate inflation.
It is high inflation and low in flow of direct investment
from USA and Europe that has short circuited the
growth story. India can't make large investment
because it runs 8 % -9% budget deficit. S&P is
gearing up to downgrade India which would
discourage foreign investment.

It is also OK for India to exhibit schadenfreude in this matter, but they should not also overlook the long sordid history of the US looking the other way at Pakistan's rogue outlaw behavior towards India.

And It is not for fear of antagonizing the Chinese that India is cautious over defense ties with the US. India is no rentier banana republic like Pakistan. It is not going to blindly accept discarded US technology, which could be held back any time that the US suddenly decides to play footsie with the Chinese.

The question arose because about 140 Pakistani soldiers were killed by an avalanche. Both Pakistan and India have known for long years the rigours of service in this sector. We heard that here four fifths of the casualties were because of the weather and barely one fifth as casualties of war.
Now, Pakistan and especially its army chief Gen Kayani has made a virtue of a necessity. It makes eminent sense for both countries to withdraw their troops from this sector. But, of course, there has to be affirmation of the present ground situation for the demilitarization to take place.
All that will go very well with India and many in the Indian decision making echelons may be prepared to support the idea. What they do not seem to foresee is the following.
We all know about the Pakistan-China nexus. When both Indian and Pakistani troops have withdrawn from Siachen, what is there to prevent the Chinese from just walking in? China's own borders in this region are not defined or demarcated. It is facile for Pakistan to argue for joint Indo-Pak withdrawal, thereby paving the way for Chinese occupation.
It is not in the Indian interest to agree to demilitarization of Siachen under any conditions, regardless of the willingness or unwillingness of Pakistan to define the present AGPL.
The current Indo-Pak talks on the subject are a charade. They cannot produce any result. In the end the diplomats will disperse, having gained better understanding of each other's views.
V. C. Bhutani, Delhi

All this wealth has not disappeared, it's just flowing into the pockets of the new class of billionaires. In my mind's eye I see the invisible vacuum hoses sapping the strength out of the walls of homes, out of savings accounts, out of refrigerators and dresser drawers. Look at all the useless things that we've come to accept or depend on: insurances of every variety, lawyers, IRAs - forget it, that money is gone unless the Ponzi masters get their way, cable, deadly medications for achy finger syndrome, hospital stays of a few days that could cost six figures, university degrees that are little more than branding, unfathomably costly wars and defense budgets and national debt service. Who owns that debt? How do we unwind this all?

“Decreases in incomes were much larger for the higher education groups, and mean income actually rose for the no-high-school-diploma group,” indicates two things that might not show up in the unemployment data economists are looking at:
The "no-high-school-diploma group,” is made up of street smart survivors, very resilient out of necessity, and they can bounce into a wide variety of labor jobs, what ever is available, even self employment with a truck and a lawn mower. Necessity is indeed the Mother of Invention. Survive at all cost!

The "higher education groups" are anything but street smart survivors and become ego crippled deer in headlights without a sense of direction or a native thought of how to transition from a vanished white collar to a calloused blue collar. They might also be more inclined and capable of spending a few years without income while they pursue a new education for future employment.

It is much easier to eliminate or out source middle class jobs than blue collar jobs.
